div.p: >>Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

Let's
look at creating a class.

Suppose you decide to start
a house sitting business
and you decide that one

of the classes you'll need
is a house sitting contract

that holds data about
each contract you have
with the client.

You might decide
some of the data

that you'll need is a clients
name as a string and the number

of days of the contract
as a numeric variable.

Typically when you create
a class you make most data
to be private.

Making the data private
constructs a sort of barrier

around it that prevents outside
classes or outside programs
from using the data in any way

that the class has
not approved of.

For example, suppose
you start a program

and you declare a house sitting
contract object, named contract.

If you decide to assign a
value to contract.client,

when you attempt to access
the client, you can't get in.
The data is private.
This statement is illegal.

Instead what you have to do
is create a method with a name

like set client that can accept
a clients name as a parameter
and make the assignment.

This method is public, meaning
an outside program can use it.

So in your program if you say,
contract.set client and pass

in an argument, this is a
call to the set client method.

The name is passed in as
a parameter to the method.

The method makes the assignment
and the method is allowed

to make the assignment because
it's part of the same class.

A class method can get
at its own classes data.

Here's a more detailed public
method called set days.

It accepts the number of days in
a contract and assigns it only
if it's within the proper range.

This method declares a maximum
number of days and checks

to make sure the days passed
and don't exceed that.

This is a better example of
why you sometimes want methods

to protect your private
data from being set in ways

that the class does
not agree with.

So if you make a
statement in your program

like contract set days,
this calls the public method

and sends in the
argument as a parameter.

The parameter can then be
assigned and the method can get

at its own data and
make the assignment.
Here's a statement that attempts

to output the contracts
clients name.

When you try to get the
clients name, it can't get
out because the data is private.
This is an illegal statement.
Instead, what you might want

to do is add a public
method called get client

that returns the clients
name to an outside program.

You might add a name to
your program, a string,

and then you might
assign contract.get client
to that name.

Contract.get client is a
method call and the method

in the class can
access its own data

and that can be returned
to the outside.
Then you might output the name.

Incidentally these
two statements,
name equals contract.get client

and then output name could
be combined into one,
output contract.get client.

You could add another
public method to your class
to return the private days

and then you could output
the days within the program.

When you finish a class you
typically add an end class

statement and when you finish
your program, of course,

you typically add
a stop statement.

That's a quick look at
creating and using a class.
Thanks for watching.
